title: UK's 'first ever selfie' goes on display - 136 years after it was snapped
text:

A self­ie believed to be the oldest in the UK has gone on display 136 years after it was snapped.

The black and white photo from 1883 was taken by inventor and engineer Washington Teasdale after sett­ing up his camera pointing at Kirkstall Abbey and hot-footing it to a bench in time to be in the picture.

The image is on show at Leeds Industrial Museum, two miles from where the photo was taken.

Curator Chris Sharp said photography expert Washington had “a truly remarkable mind” and a “prodigious intellect”.

“Despite his many notable accomplishments he is also far from a household name.

“These unsung heroes of science and engineering have helped put Leeds on the map in their own unique way, pushing the boundaries of science and engineering and leaving a lasting legacy that we’re proud to celebrate today.”

Born in Leeds, Teasdale trained as an engineer and worked in India on the railways before moving back to Britain and pursuing his love of photography.

(Image: Leeds City Council / SWNS)

He was a founding member of the Leeds Photographic Society, the Royal Society of Microscopy and was a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society.

Teasdale’s greatest achievement was arguably inventing the ‘field naturalist’s microscope’, a portable instrument of magnification.

He used it to study insects and capture detailed images of the moon through a telescope.

Teasdale died in 1903 at the age of 73 while attending a meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The first ever selfie, which is a ‘photograph taken by oneself’, is considered to have been taken by American pioneer Robert Cornelius in 1839.

Modern selfie culture emerged in Japan in the 1990s and has exploded within the past 15 years with the dawn of social media.

It’s estimated 93 million selfies are posted online every day.

(Image: Getty)

Teasdale’s example is part of a new exhibition at Leeds Industrial Museum telling the illustrious history of engineering in the West Yorkshire city.

Councillor Judith Blake, leader of Leeds City Council, said: “Leeds has a very long and proud history as a centre of innovation and progress stretching back hundreds of years.

“The pioneers who feature in this exhibition are among those who helped blaze a trail in a myriad of fields and industries, inspiring generations of scientists and engineers to follow in their footsteps and play their part in building the city we know today.”

Leeds-born Washington died in 1903 aged 73.

His achievements include inventing a type of portable microscope.

The first ever selfie is thought to have been taken in the US in 1839.
